Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of ET-AR Antagonist in Post-Cardiac Surgery Inflammation

Trial_Design.evidence: Forty-four patients undergoing cardiac surgery were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive a bolus infusion of vehicle or ET-AR antagonist (sitaxsentan)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigated the effect of an endothelin-A receptor (ET-AR) antagonist on tumor necrosis factor (TNF) activation post-cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Plasma levels of TNF-α and soluble TNF receptors 1 and 2 were measured at baseline and 24 hours post-infusion.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty-four patients undergoing cardiac surgery were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 24 hours, the 1 mg/kg ET-AR antagonist group showed reduced plasma levels of TNF-α and TNF receptor 2 compared to the vehicle group (mean difference ~13 pg/mL and ~0.5 ng/mL, respectively; p<0.05).
